threads.com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

>>1273453
Countries like Romania, Finland, Yugoslavia and Greece are definetly more important to WWII than Portugal, Ethiopia or the Commonwealth nations in terms of focus trees.
Since focus trees allow you to deviate from history, it's clear that nations that could've easily go down a different route should be a priority.
I can see why Spain and Poland are important because if they did anything different, the conflict might've looked very, very different.
Etiophia is too peripheral and early to make an impact and the Commonwealth and Hungary I guess were kinda "locked in" into their role.
But Romania started alligned with the Allies, became an Axis nation and eventually a begrudgent Soviet puppet.
Finland started at war with the Soviets and ended it trying to kick out the Germans.
Greece got dragged into the conflict too, despite being more ideologically alligned with Axis powers.
Yugoslavia was such a mess I won't even go into it.
What choices that come with a focus tree could be considered realistic for Canada or Australia?
I could see an argument for India, but most of it is post-war stuff.

>army management (army depletes as you advance because you have to leave troops behind to garrison)
>making the world evolve (you turn forests into farmlands, build bridges over rivers, convert villages to cities)

The war system itself is something of a lovechild of CK2/3 and Vic2. The goal is to depict localized warfare, and avert total war, however, make it more flexible than CK2/3's model, hence pic related diagram.
I was going to write a more detailed greentext about it, but realize nobody will read it.
But the gist is that war is centered around occupying target areas (like the war goals in CK2/3).
The war is tied to three: phases, invasion, counter-invasion, and inter-invasion
>a campaign ends in attacker's victory if they are able to occupy the entire area
>a campaign ends in defender's victory if the campaign has lasted 12 months and the attacker hasn't occupied a single province within the target area
>if the invader wins the campaign, and wishes to invade another area, a new invasion will commence
>if the invader wins the campaign, but wishes for peace, out but the defender wants to continue, counter-invasion commences
>if both parties want peace, the war ends

Also, you can only occupy enemy territories within the target area, this

last_replies.com:
>>1276227
the default game mode is about capturing and controlling special provinces with Thrones of Ascension on them. you do that by sending armies of units, commanded by leaders who are also units, into those provinces.
Battles are automatic, but you can program your units and leaders to do certain things, like casting a few spells or waiting for the leader to cast spells before going in on the offence.
before you start the match you first pick an age (EA has more magic, LA has more tech, MA is middleground), a faction (it doesn't really matter who you pick here as everyone is viable, but you might have some preferences and for that there's guides on what nations do what and how), and a custom Pretender who'll be your faction's god figure (complete with Blessings that your holy units might be blessed with by your holy commanders, as well as Scales that give small but noticeable buffs and debuffs to your nation's overall prosperity).
After all that setup you'll drop on the map with one province, your Capital, to your name, no idea what's around you, and usually one sneaky Scout commander who's fast, one non-sneaky Leader commander who starts with an army, and your Pretender alive and ready to kick ass (if you selected Awake Pretender; ass kickery levels depend on the pretender's unit stats). The goal is to expand fast, usually one or two provinces every turn, so by the end of turn 12 (first year) you hopefully have 20 or so provinces or have found the opponent nations' borders and started doing diplomacy. Within the provinces it is also important to build structures so you can recruit from more than just your capital, and to send your mages to search for Magic Sites that provide currency for casting endgame spells. After that it boils down to who can get the most broken combo of effects and spells ever, and who gets it fast enough to stop everyone else from getting theirs.

>Will going from using a mouse and some keys to using only hotkeys increase my chances of winning in ao2 de?
It will allow you to execute actions much faster. If you are in all other ways equal to your opponent (in game knowledge, build order knowledge, multitasking/macro, micro, "game sense" etc) then being faster than them is a pretty significant advantage. It doesn't guarantee a win over them, because it's still up to you to make the most of your advantage. If you're faster to feudal / castle and are ahead in eco because of your superior speed, but don't use this to beat your opponent, then it doesn't matter how fast you are.

last_replies.com:
>>1275710
>How do I manage money in this game
if you're just looking to succeed with minimal game knowledge and have no desire to speedrun? pauper for a week, king for a day
scrimp and save, spend as little as possible to keep the warband running while still having a bit of a cushion food/tools/medswise
then when you hit a certain plateau, for me it's usually 5-10k, you make a major expansion in some regard
before returning to saving money for the next expansion
ie grabbing three new dudes all at once, or upgrading a couple people's gear or filling up tools and food (these two are usually my first port of call since they increase how long you can operate without pit stops) or whatever else you may have in mind, you want to commit to a measureable change in party composition or material on hand
I recommend going for big skews rather than small ones as well, like a lot of people who play at a high level will focus on snowballing lots of small factors, but when you're starting out you want big noticeable changes that you can track and assess. do this often enough and the worth of smaller changes will become apparent naturally.
don't let yourself be limited by it, but the squad goals system gives you a good guideline for the mindset you should be in
like how "we want 3 heavy armour boys" translates to "we need enough money for 3 high-mid end helms and suits", you'll generally not buy them piecemeal, you'll grab them all at once. this allows you to have a cushion for operating costs in the meantime, and when you get three heavy armour boys all at once you'll notice the fuckin difference immediately
the hard part is suppressing the urge to make smaller plays along the way, like if you see a deal on a tier 3 weapon or something. it might be the objectively correct choice, but it's probably not the choice that will benefit a beginner more than staying focused on pushing towards that big skew

Different perspectives.

The Protectorate is like a criminal holed up inside a house yelling to the police that he'll only surrender if they'll meet his demands.
The Servants are like the wife in an abusive relationship saying that she can "change him".

Trying to see things from their point of view, this is why they do what they do:
The Servants see the aliens as superior, but have no desire to be slaves. They feel like they can help, even heal the Hydra (once they figure out their trauma) and reason that the only real way to get their trust is to show unconditional servitude.
The aliens are here to defang humanity through mind control enslavement and by pointing orbital guns at us. To convince them to let us serve them out of free will makes them feel uncomfortable and takes some actual convincing.
The Protectorate from their side are like you handing over your wallet to an armed robber because all you want is to get him to leave.
To them, a guaranteed enslaved humanity and an intact Earth is worth more then a destroyed planet and an exterminated humanity but a small chance of victory.
They want to negotiate humanity's surrender by getting a deal does less harm then trying to fight them would. They fall for the sunk cost fallacy.

threads.com:
Why are hexfags so fucking retarded they cannot see the forest for the trees?

See picrel for why why the "diagonal movement problem" hexfags try to ascribe to squares doesn't actually exist - because you are moving in tiles, not actual distance! It doesn't matter that you have moved 1.41 feet diagonally, when you would have moved only 1 foot orthgonaly, becasue YOU ARE NOT MOVING IN REAL DISTANCE, YOU ARE MOVING IN TILES.
See picrel, it takes the exact same amount of tiles to move from one corner to the next diagonally, that it takes to move from one corner to the next orthogonally.
Yes the real distance is larger, but that does not matter, since the game is structured in tiles, not real distance!

Hexxfagging is unirinically Reddit-style thinking - believing you are some sort of expert and can overturn years of time-tested methods because you have learned some arbitrary fun fact (in this case that distance from one center of a square to the center of diagonal square is larger than the distance to the center of a orthogonal square).

TL;DR: 1 tile = 1 tile, always

>What's the appeal of this game?
build autismo, mainly, since there is an absurd amount of interactions between the masteries and such.
but it also has very interesting things that make its tactical layer better than NuCom's
>dynamic turn system instead of 'i go, you go'
>terrain matters beyond mere height difference
>even time of the day and climate matter
>chain effects (ie: pushing an enemy into an obstacle or someone else stuns them, a flashbang in the dark causes confusion instead of blind, receiving a lightning crit while on water stuns you, etc)

> I don't get it, does it get any better later on?
it does, and it is arguably the weak point of the game, that it takes too long to actually be able to exploit all the mechanics the game has since the early game is extremely limited in how many mastery slots and characters you have (also since your characters have low speed and there aren't many ways to reduce your AT, it is also very slow and you'll have to wait a lot between turns)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1264462
Vicky 2 has a lot of problems and really is not that fun of a game in single player, anon. Vicky 2 is summed up by "great concept, terrible execution" and that mantra holds true for basically every aspect of the game - from the Scramble for Africa to the Crisis system.
Most PDX games, the gimmick is that you start small and gradually build up. In CK2, players are told that characters above emperor are "pointless" to play, for example. But with Vicky, the game isn't worth playing unless you are one of the ~12 powers who is a GP or can easily become one (Japan, China, Mexico, CSA, Netherlands, Spain, etc.). Nations that are less powerful than that simply have so little control that you are at the mercy of AI superpowers. The game isn't long enough for a small nation like, say, Afghanistan to work its way up to the global superpower.
The main appeal of Vicky 2 is that it's a "simulator" for the 19th century. You're playing an alternate history, that sort of thing. However, the AI isn't good enough to do anything interesting most times. In reality, the Victorian era had many. many close calls where different powers nearly got colonies in weird places (Russia tried to colonize Hawaii, Belgium tried to colonize Texas after it beat Mexico, Russia tried to colonize Djibouti, etc.). You will never see Russian Hawaii even though it's actually historically plausible.
The game is overly rigid due to the limitations of the events/decision system for railroading. Like, powers regularly sold territory to one another at the time, but there is no system for dynamic sales. Instead, it's a handful of railroaded ones that occurred historically, like the Alaskan Purchase.
Great concept, terrible execution.

>Prior to release, a preliminary but completely workable version of the game engine was used in two series of TV programs: Decisive Battles by the History Channel where it was used to recreate famous historical battles,[17] and Time Commanders by BBC Two, where teams of novice non-gamers commanded ancient armies to replay key battles of antiquity. The game engine was fine-tuned specifically for these television shows by military historians for maximum historical accuracy.
